titleStmt.title: EDWARD M. MORGAN and THOMAS F. MURPHY TO Margaret Sanger April 2, 1914

note.p: Under 480 of the Postal Laws and Regulations"> regarding obscene materials, local postmasters were required to contact the William Lamar Assistant Attorney General for the Post Office Department for a determination on whether specific matter deposited in the mail was obscene under Section 211 of the U.S. Criminal Code, and therefore unmailable. The Assistant Attorney General could suppress either individual issues of a publication, as in the case of The Woman Rebel, or he could suppress an entire publication.

body.p: In accordance with advice from the William Lamar Assistant Attorney General for the Post Office Department, you are informed that the publication entitled “The Woman Rebel”, for March 1914, is unmailable under the provisions of Section 211 of the Criminal Code as amended by the Act of March 4, 1911.
Copies of the March 1914 issue found in the mail are held at Washington Bridge Station of the New York Post Office where they may be obtained by calling for the same and exhibiting this letter.
body.closer:
Very respectfully,
E. M. Morgan(stamped)
Per Th. F. Murphy, (singed)
Assistant Postmaster
